content: I’m not sure this goes against aggregation theory. From Ben’s post: “no longer do distributors compete based upon exclusive supplier relationships, with consumers/users an afterthought. Instead, suppliers can be aggregated at scale leaving consumers/users as a first order priority.” Nobody here owns distribution. Zomato can decide, just like Swiggy has, that delivery times have an outsized outcome on user experience and work to improve them. “By extension, this means that the most important factor determining success is the user experience: the best distributors/aggregators/market-makers win by providing the best experience..” So though it definitely matters, distribution is not a chokepoint, and sure, people are less likely to change once they’ve signed up but that doesn’t mean Swiggy already won. They’ve only lived so far.
